sourceDesc.p: The primary source of the transcription is the rock engraved with the excerpt. Many characters had become illegible due to weathering of past centuries. As a rule, these are supplied from the Taishō version in the transcription.

The Buddha said, “Good man, what is named piercing the bodhi [enlightenment] mind? When a bodhisattva has already put forth the bodhi mind, he never again gives rise to the semblance of a ‘Self’. If a bodhisattva is not attached to the bodhi mind; if a bodhisattva does not crave the bodhi mind; if a bodhi­sat­tva does not yearn for the bodhi mind; if a bodhi­sat­tva does not contemplate the bodhi mind, then, in such a way, a bodhisattva is able to make the mind quiescent and tranquil, to contemplate the deep [deep] Dharma Realm and to contemplate the Teaching of the Buddhas [Buddha-Dharma].

The ‘deep Dharma Realm’ means that the Twelve [Fold Chain of] Dependent Origination far transcends the two extremes [of either existing or non-existing]. All dharmas are, without exception, intrinsically by nature without self. Contemplating the nature of the self, the nature of all dharmas is that they are empty and without a controlling principle. Believing in the Absorption [samadhis] of Emptiness, of being devoid of attributes, and of being devoid of aspiration, a bodhisattva knows that, among all conditioned dharmas, there is none which is created. He contemplates Form as like foam, Feeling as like water bubbles, Perception as like mirage, Volition as like the [coreless trunk of the] banana tree, and Consciousness as like an illusion. He contemplates that form is not created, and that there is nothing which is moved; that the [Six] Sense Organs are as if deaf and blind, and that the mind does not rest even for a moment; that the bonds of pride and arrogance have no place at all where they can arise; that all dharmas are non-dual and without differentiation. They are of one flavor, one vehicle, one way, one origin. The bodhisattva contemplates that all sounds are without the attributes of sound; that all tones and sounds, appearing in sequence, do not cohere; that all dharmas, without exception, cannot be expressed in speech. He fully knows the attributes of Suffering, that Accumulation has nothing pertaining to the self, the remainderless Extinction [of suffering], and he completely knows the Path.

Because he is unimpeded and unobstructed, he contemplates the Station of the Mindfulness of the Body, knows that Feelings come and go, is mindful of the Mind’s emergence and extinction, and knows the Dharma Realm. Contemplating the [Dharma] Realm as no Realm is cultivating Correct Effort. In order to attain mastery, one cultivates the Bases of Supernatural [Power]. Transcending defilements is named the Root of Faith; delighting in quiescence is named the Root of Vigorous Effort; because it lacks [conceptual] mindfulness, it is named the Root of Mindfulness; because it is not thinking, it is named the Root of Concentration; [because] it far transcends everything, it is named the Root of Wisdom. [root.] Not following others is named the Power of Faith; being unimpeded and unobstructed is named the Power of Vigorous Effort; not regressing is named the Power of Mindfulness; the mind attaining mastery is named the Power of Concentration; not contemplating good and evil is named the Power of Wisdom. Not indulging oneself is named the Mindfulness Limb of Awakening; entering into dharmas is named the Discrimination of the Dharmas Limb of Awakening; practicing in accordance with the Dharma [practicing in accordance with the Dharma] is named the Vigorous Effort Limb of Awakening; far transcending evil is named the Joy Limb of Awakening; body and mind being tranquil is named the Detachment Limb of Awakening; knowing real absorption is named the Concentration Limb of Awakening; not contemplating in terms of duality is named the Relinquishment Limb of Awakening. Far transcending all views is named Correct View; transcending suppositions and analyses is named Correct Thought; knowing the nature of sounds [sounds] is named Correct Speech; with regard to body, speech and mind, not giving rise to craving or attachment is named Correct Action; transcending the envious mind is named Correct Livelihood; neither increasing nor reducing is named Correct Vigorous Effort; with regard to the good or the not good, not giving rise to craving and attachment is named Correct Mindfulness; contemplating mental realms is named Correct Concentration.

As for the nature of the real attribute, its nature [nature] is quiescent and tranquil. From the point of view of ultimate meaning we name it Impermanence, Suffering, and No-self. Conventionally, we name it as clarity and purity, as Great Purity. Being able to harmonize the mind is named Generosity; clarity and coolness of body and mind is named Discipline; the impermanence of dharmas is named Patience; diligently cultivating this knowledge is named Vigorous Effort; internal and external clarity and purity are named Absorption; because of contemplating true reality, it is named Wisdom. Knowing that the nature of the minds of all beings is fundamentally pure; this is named Loving Kindness; contemplating that everything is the same as empty space; this is named Compassion; cutting off all joy; this is named the Joyful Mind; keeping distant from all conditioned things; this is named the Relinquishing Mind. All dharmas, without exception, are pure with regard to the future time, are manifold with regard to the past, and are without self with regard to the present.

Good man, if you can truly and really investigate and fully know such dharmas, this is named the jewel of piercing the bodhi mind. When the bodhisattva has investigated such dharmas, he will progressively attain the dhāraṇī
of mastery with respect to all dharmas.

Good man, it is just like the sun and moon; they do not intentionally come and go [each day] and shine, but because of the power of the virtue and merit of all beings, of themselves they depart and return, destroying the darknesses.

Good man, the bodhisattva-mahāsattva , who is able to contemplate and comprehend such dharmas, is also like this. He does not think: ‘I shall benefit countless beings’, and yet he causes beings to attain great benefit.
Good man, when the bodhisattva-mahāsattva truly and really knows such dharmas, this is named Abiding that is Non-Abiding.”

When the Buddha preached this Dharma, twelve nayuta of beings set their minds on Unsurpassed Correct Perfect Enlightenment [ anuttarā samyak-saṃbodhi ], and sixteen thousand gods attained the Acceptance that all Dharmas are Without Birth.

The received version in the woodblock printed canon transmits zhu 住, and indeed, “abiding in the absorption” (zhu sanmei 住三昧) is the common phrase one would expect, while “believing in the absorption” is very unusual. It may be a mistake.
The three modes of samadhi are: Absorption of Emptiness (kong sanmei 空三昧), Absorption of No-attributes (wuxiang sanmei 無相三昧), and Absorption of No-desire (wuyuan sanmei 無願三昧).

Reading reyan 熱炎 as reshi yan 熱時炎, a mirage, or the atmospheric phenomenon that produces deceptive images of distant objects like water when light is refracted in very hot air.
The Sutra on the Metaphor of the Five Aggregates (Wuyin piyu jing 五陰譬喻經, T#105, 2: a1–c4; here b18–20), attributed to the Parthian monk An Shigao 安世高 (arrived in Luoyang in 148), has a parallel passage which says: “Accumulating foam bears analogy with Form, Pain [i.e. Feelings] is comparable to water bubbles, Perception is similar to a mirage, Volition is like the [coreless trunk of the] banana tree; therefore, Illusion is likened to Consciousness.” 沫聚喻於色，痛如水中泡，想譬熱時炎，行為若芭蕉，夫幻喻如識。
Form, Feeling, Perception, Volition, and Consciousness comprise the Five Aggregates (wuyun 五蘊 or wuyin 五陰), which are said to make up the composite nature of beings.
Here ru 入 means the Six Sense Organs (liu ru 六入) that produce sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch, and thought.

“Has nothing pertaining to the self” is rendered in Chinese on the rock of Mount Tie as wu wowu 無我无. The last character is obviously a mistake and should instead read suo 所. The Taishō edition also has wu wosuo 無我所. See T#278, 9: 546b22–24.

This is a restatement of the Four Noble Truths. Though “Noble Truth” is the standard translation for this term, K.R. Norman has argued that it is the least probable possibility, suggesting instead, “truth of the noble one.” See 16.

These are the Four Stations of Mindfulness (si nianchu 四念處), namely Mindfulness of the Body ( kāyasmṛtyupasthāna ; guan shen nianchu 觀身念處, also shen nianzhu 身念住), Mindfulness of Feelings ( vedanāsmṛtyupasthānāna ; shou nianchu 受念處), Mindfulness of the [ever-changing] Mind ( cittasmṛtyupasthānāna ; xin nianchu 心念處), and Mindfulness of the [insubstantial nature of] Dharmas ( dharmasmṛtyupasthānāna ; fa nianchu 法念處). The first one, Mindfulness of the Body, is one of the basic practices of mindfulness in the Buddhist tradition. It is named in several different lists of such practices, including, most prominently, the Four Stations of Mindfulness, but also the Ten Stations of Mindfulness (shi nianchu 十念處). In a particular passage in the Mahāparinirvāṇa-sūtra (Da bo niepan jing 大般涅槃經, T#374, 12: 433c26–434b23) translated by Dharmakṣema, this practice consists of meditation on the fact that the attributes of the body are impure. In the Great Collection Sutra, as in many later formulations, this is inverted, and the meditation is on the basic purity, or unobstructedness, or emptiness, of the body and all phenomena. 261–262 translates the core passage on the “pure practice” (jingxing 淨行) of the Mindfulness of the Body from the Great Collection Sutra, T#397, 13: 176c7–12, and explains that several teachings of the Mahayana constitute Buddhahood by means of the Buddha’s metaphysical body ( dharmakāya ; fashen 法身) that is held to be identical to Suchness ( tathatā ; zhenru 真如), the true reality pertaining to all phenomena, which, in turn, is pure.
See in the same text T#397, 13: 17a22–23 觀法平等無去來，若能觀見無出滅.
Correct Effort (zheng qin 正勤) represents here all of the Four Correct Efforts, which are part of the Thirty-seven Factors of Enlightenment.

On the rock surface of Mount Tie, the character zu 足 is added after ruyi 如意. The Taishō edition only has ruyi 如意. In this way, the rock cut version clarifies the meaning of Bases of Supernatural [Power] (ruyizu 如意足) as an allusion to the Four Bases of Magical [Power] (si shenzu 四神足 or si ruyizu 四如意足), which are also part of the Thirty-seven Factors of Enlightenment.

The link between the nominal designation and ultimate reality is also described in the Flower Adornment Sutra. See T#279, 10: 311b26–27. “Now I, because of the body of nominal designation, shall attain the Thus Come One’s full and complete unsurpassed Dharma Body of the Three Times.” 我今因此假名身故。當得如來充滿三世無上法身。

The four items bring to mind the Four Inverted Views (si diandao 四顛倒) of Permanence (chang 常), Enjoyment (le 樂), Self (wo 我) and Purity (jing 淨). See the Great Parinirvāṇa Sutra, T#374, 12: 377c6–8 樂中見苦。常見無常。我見無我。淨見不淨。是名顛倒。
These are the Four Immeasurable States of Mind (si wuliangxin 四無量心; catvāri apramāṇāni ): Loving Kindness (ci 慈), Compassion (bei 悲), Joy (xi 喜) and Relinquishment (she 捨).

Dhāraṇī (tuoluoni 陀羅尼) here refers, not to a kind of incantation, but to a mystically comprehensive “hold” or “support” (the root meaning of the Sanskrit term, which is reflected in its usual Chinese translation as chi 持), of one’s own being amidst the infinity of entities. See . Attaining the dhāraṇī of sovereignty is a common trope throughout Dharmakṣema’s translation of the Great Collection Sutra.

The notion that the sun’s rising and setting are controlled by the action (karma) of all beings is a very old idea, dating back to at least the Brāhmaṇa literature. The daily fire offering ( agnihotra ) is perhaps the best example of ritual action ensuring the continued movements of the sun. See 3ff.

The light of sun and moon is likened to the light of the Buddha, as a similar verse in the same sutra (T#397, 13: 4a19) elucidates: “The light of the sun and moon destroys the present night; the light of the Buddha can destroy the darkness of the three times (past, present and future).” 日月光明壞現冥。佛光能壞三世闇。
Cut onto the rock are the characters de da 得大, “attain great” benefit. The Taishō edition has these characters inverted as da de 大得, which would translate as “greatly attain” benefit.
Repetition of character re 若 [jñā] at the top of the column.

The stone cut text differs in the character wu 无 from the Taishō version, which has “…is none other than what is named Attribute” (ming zhi wei xiang 名之爲相). In this case, the stone cut character seems to be a mistake; the Taishō text is more coherent.

The text on Mount Tie, wusheng wumie ming wuxiang xiang 无生无滅名无相相, differs here from the received version collated in Taishō (T#397, 13: 50c7), which adds the term “devoid of attributes”, wuxiang 无相, to this sentence and reads wu­sheng wumie ming wuxiang wuxiang xiang 无生无滅 名无相无相相.
This Sanskrit term perhaps comes closest in meaning to an English word like “zillions”, if that were an accepted English term.
